item.title: Brussels flights halted after suspected drone sightings
item.description: Flights were suspended at the main airport in Belgium's capital after suspected drone sightings, a Brussels Airport spokesman said.
item.source:markdown: Flights were suspended at the main airport in Belgium's capital after suspected drone sightings, a Brussels Airport spokesman said.

item.title: Pope: ‘Spiritual rights’ of migrant detainees must be respected
item.description:
In remarks to journalists in Castel Gandolfo, Pope Leo calls for “deep reflection” on the treatment of migrants in the United States, urges "dialogue" between the US and Venezuela, appeals for countries to "work together for justice for all peoples" in Israel-Palestine, and expresses his hope that the trial of ex-Jesuit Marko Rupnik will "bring clarity and justice for everyone involved".

Read all
item.source:markdown:
In remarks to journalists in Castel Gandolfo, Pope Leo calls for “deep reflection” on the treatment of migrants in the United States, urges "dialogue" between the US and Venezuela, appeals for countries to "work together for justice for all peoples" in Israel-Palestine, and expresses his hope that the trial of ex-Jesuit Marko Rupnik will "bring clarity and justice for everyone involved".
[Read all](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/pope/news/2025-11/pope-us-migrants-spiritual-rights-venezuela-gaza-work-rupnik.html)

item.title: Bird flu outbreak at commercial turkey flock in Carlow
item.description: Restriction zones have been put in place around a commercial turkey farm in Co Carlow, after an outbreak of the highly pathogenic H5N1 strain of avian influenza, or bird flu was detected there.
item.source:markdown: Restriction zones have been put in place around a commercial turkey farm in Co Carlow, after an outbreak of the highly pathogenic H5N1 strain of avian influenza, or bird flu was detected there.

item.title: Government's fortune rests on delivery of housing
item.description: Not for the first time, the Government's fortunes rest on housing delivery. That weight of expectation is also vested in the Coalition's long overdue revamped Housing Plan, writes Political Reporter Sandra Hurley.

item.title: Sign language teams to assist in sexual abuse court case
item.description: The jury in the trial of seven men accused of sexually abusing a deaf family member has been told the court is in "new territory", with a number of sign language interpretation teams in place to assist the process.
item.source:markdown: The jury in the trial of seven men accused of sexually abusing a deaf family member has been told the court is in "new territory", with a number of sign language interpretation teams in place to assist the process.

item.title: Man jailed for 15 months over Thornton Hall pig stabbings
item.description: A former IT worker has been jailed for 15 months for two acts of animal cruelty linked to protests against asylum seeker housing.
item.source:markdown: A former IT worker has been jailed for 15 months for two acts of animal cruelty linked to protests against asylum seeker housing.

item.title: Meat plant worker gets €20k for maternity discrimination
item.description: A meatpacking worker who said she was transferred to physically tougher duties after telling her manager she was pregnant – before he cut her shifts – has been awarded €20,000 for maternity-related discrimination.
item.source:markdown: A meatpacking worker who said she was transferred to physically tougher duties after telling her manager she was pregnant – before he cut her shifts – has been awarded €20,000 for maternity-related discrimination.

item.title: Cameroon: Genuine dialogue is the only way forward, says Archbishop Nkea
item.description:
This week, as the world shifted its gaze from post-electoral turmoil in Cameroon to Tanzania, the Archbishop of Bamenda and President of the National Episcopal Conference of Cameroon, Archbishop Andrew Nkea Fuanya, shares some of his thoughts with Vatican News on what could be the way forward for Cameroon. Archbishop Nkea was in Rome recently, leading over 100 “Pilgrims of Hope" visiting Rome and other holy sites for the 2025 Jubilee of Hope. The pilgrimage, which started on 24 October, conclude

item.title: Method to identify female dinosaurs discovered at Queen's
item.description: Female dinosaurs can be identified by traumatic bone injuries in tailbones, according to research conducted at Queen's University in Belfast.

item.title: Woman pleads guilty to killing boy, 4, denies murder

item.title: Trump's agenda faces early test in regional elections
item.description: Voters in New Jersey and Virginia will choose their next governors today in a pair of races that will serve as an early gauge of the American electorate's mood after US President Donald Trump's norm-shattering nine months in office.

item.title: EC expresses 'concern' in wake of new phone location data exposé

item.title: Ireland faces falling tax revenues as population ages
item.description: Ireland faces a surge in the number of older people as a proportion of the population, falling tax revenues and increased fiscal deficits, according to a new report by the Department of Finance.

item.title: World will overshoot 1.5C temperature rise goal, UN says
item.description: The world has failed to meet its main climate change target of limiting the rise in global temperatures to 1.5 degrees Celsius, and will likely breach this threshold in the next decade, the United Nations' Environment Programme has said.

item.title: Restarting the Economy: Rethinking Economics in the Light of the Jubilee
item.description:
From 28 to 30 November, in Castel Gandolfo, Restarting the Economy — the global meeting promoted by The Economy of Francesco — will take place. An international event aimed at rethinking the economy in light of the Jubilee, focusing on social justice, care for the Earth, and freedom from debt.

item.title: World leaders adopt Doha declaration to boost efforts on social development

item.title: Around 224 million women still don’t access family planning
item.description: Since 1990, the number of people using modern contraception methods has doubled globally but despite this, nearly 224 million women in mainly developing regions still do not use safe and effective family planning methods, according to the UN sexual and reproductive health agency, UNFPA.
item.source:markdown: Since 1990, the number of people using modern contraception methods has doubled globally but despite this, nearly 224 million women in mainly developing regions still do not use safe and effective family planning methods, according to the UN sexual and reproductive health agency, UNFPA.

item.title: LIVE from Doha: Second World Summit for Social Development
item.description: Leaders, policymakers and civil society representatives have gathered in Doha for the Second World Summit for Social Development, with the aim of renewing global commitments to inclusion, dignity and social justice. UN News is on the ground, bringing you live updates, key highlights and human stories from inside the conference halls and beyond. Follow this page for rolling coverage throughout the Summit. App users can follow the coverage here.

item.title: Famine declared in two Sudanese cities cut off by war, fragile gains elsewhere

item.title: Syria’s future under threat from acute funding shortages

item.title: New climate pledges do little to correct global warming projection, UN warns
item.description: Available new climate pledges by governments have only slightly lowered global temperature rise over the course of this century, leaving the world on the path to a serious escalation of climate risks and damages.

item.title: Gaza: Aid teams race to push back hunger; one million food parcels delivered

item.title: Shein vows to cooperate with France in sex doll inquiry

item.title: Win or lose at the Supreme Court, Trump has other tariff tools at his disposal
item.description: The U.S. Supreme Court takes on a major case on Wednesday when it decides if President Donald Trump has the authority to use a law usually cited in emergencies for the imposition of tariffs on other countries. While they may not be as blunt as the law Trump has cited, there are a handful of other laws the president can cite to utilize tariffs for leverage and revenue.
item.source:markdown:
![An older cleanshaven blonde-haired man wearing a suit and yellow tie is shown speaking in closeup.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/0f6713bc-9fe6-448a-894e-0ce85d246f66,1762269509261/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C7179%2C4038%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
The U.S. Supreme Court takes on a major case on Wednesday when it decides if President Donald Trump has the authority to use a law usually cited in emergencies for the imposition of tariffs on other countries. While they may not be as blunt as the law Trump has cited, there are a handful of other laws the president can cite to utilize tariffs for leverage and revenue.

item.title: Dundalk's kit supplier begins legal action over debt
item.description: Kit supplier Playr-Fit have begun legal proceedings against Dundalk FC over an unpaid debt of €130,000, claiming they have also broken an agreement which relates to the issuing of a licence to compete in the League of Ireland last year.

item.title: COP30 in Brazil: The Amazon nears the “point of no return”
item.description:
The world’s largest tropical rainforest will host its first COP in Belém, Brazil — a symbolic choice highlighting the Amazon’s crucial role in safeguarding global biodiversity and the planet’s climate. Researcher Jhan-Carlo Espinoza of France’s Institute of Research for Development (IRD) and member of the Science Panel for the Amazon, takes stock of the situation.

Read all
item.source:markdown:

item.title: British far-right activist Tommy Robinson cleared of terror charge after not giving police phone access
item.description: Far-right activist Tommy Robinson was cleared on Tuesday of committing an offence under British counterterrorism laws after refusing to give police his phone's passcode during a July 2024 border stop.

item.title: 10 years after the UN climate pact, what did it actually do?
item.description: In 2015, nearly 200 countries adopted the Paris Agreement, the first global pact to fight climate change. Here's a comparison of then and now — in terms of the state of the climate, the way we live and our technologies, our laws and where we're putting our money.
item.source:markdown:

item.title: Millions in US to get reduced food aid during shutdown

item.title: Cuban government stealing wages from its citizens in Canada, say ex-workers
item.description: Former workers of a joint venture between the government of Cuba and Canadian mining company Sherritt International say they were victims of a wage confiscation scheme that left them to live on just a fraction of their nominal salaries. They also say they were forced to attend Communist Party meetings and provide reports on all interactions with their Canadian colleagues.
item.source:markdown:

Former workers of a joint venture between the government of Cuba and Canadian mining company Sherritt International say they were victims of a wage confiscation scheme that left them to live on just a fraction of their nominal salaries. They also say they were forced to attend Communist Party meetings and provide reports on all interactions with their Canadian colleagues.

item.title: China’s spy joke with South Korea that sounded like a warning | About That
item.description: Chinese President Xi Jinping gifted South Korean President Lee Jae Myung a pair of smartphones, jokingly telling him to 'check if there's a backdoor' — referring to the risk of unauthorized bypassing of security controls. Andrew Chang breaks down the layers of Xi's comment to better understand what may have been hidden behind the humour. Images provided by The Canadian Press, Reuters and Getty Images
item.source:markdown:
![Chinese President Xi Jinping gives two cellphones to South Korean President Lee Jae Myung in Gyeongju, South Korea.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/f03eab10-506e-4cbd-b7b5-bec96d94d564,1762217012625/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C1468%2C825%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Chinese President Xi Jinping gifted South Korean President Lee Jae Myung a pair of smartphones, jokingly telling him to 'check if there's a backdoor' — referring to the risk of unauthorized bypassing of security controls. Images provided by The Canadian Press, Reuters and Getty Images

item.title: UN agencies on hand as deadly new quake hits northern Afghanistan
item.description: UN teams rushed to northern Afghanistan on Monday after a powerful 6.3 magnitude earthquake struck overnight, just two months after a massive quake devastated the east of the country. item.title: Pope on All Souls' Day: God has opened for us the way to eternal life
item.description:
Pope Leo XIV presides over the Mass for the Commemoration of All the Faithful Departed at Rome’s Monumental Verano Cemetery. He recalls that "Christian faith, founded upon Christ’s Paschal mystery, helps us to experience our memories as more than just a recollection of the past but also, and above all, as hope for the future.” Later, he visited the crypt of Saint Peter's Basilica to pray for the deceased Popes.

item.title: 'Love makes you stronger': Mothers search for Mexico City's missing
item.description: CBC News accompanied several mothers in the search for their missing children in Mexico City. The capital is the first jurisdiction in the country to use a pattern-based strategy to find the about 7,000 people listed as disappeared in the city.
item.source:markdown:
![A woman wearing a white t-shirt with a portrait of her daughter.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/5feb6ef6-4ff9-422b-9fa4-2b958e3520e3,1761939878130/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%28222%2C192%2C487%2C273%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
CBC News accompanied several mothers in the search for their missing children in Mexico City. The capital is the first jurisdiction in the country to use a pattern-based strategy to find the about 7,000 people listed as disappeared in the city.

item.title: Italian winemakers look to new technologies with old grape varieties to adapt to a changing climate
item.description: As Italy’s vineyards grapple with summers that are longer and hotter, erratic weather and dwindling water, winemakers are being forced to rethink one of the oldest assumptions in their craft: terroir, the delicate interplay of soil, sun, wind, rain and human touch that gives each wine its specific taste.
item.source:markdown:
![A person walks through a vineyard.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/f5593ad6-3e9b-418b-9fc4-c1afa3bb368b,1761844936885/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C378%2C4032%2C2268%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
As Italy’s vineyards grapple with summers that are longer and hotter, erratic weather and dwindling water, winemakers are being forced to rethink one of the oldest assumptions in their craft: terroir, the delicate interplay of soil, sun, wind, rain and human touch that gives each wine its specific taste.

item.title: Pope: In a wartorn world, may we become builders of fraternity
item.description:
Before the recitation of the Angelus in Saint Peter’s Square, Pope Leo XIV recalled the “great celebration” to which the human family is destined—so different from the tragedies it endures because of present injustices. He also greeted the Delegation of the Church of England, in Rome for the proclamation of Saint John Henry Newman as a Doctor of the Church.

Read all
item.source:markdown:

item.title: Pope Leo XIV: Newman, Doctor of the Church - A light for the new generations
item.description:
During the Mass on the Solemnity of All Saints, also the culmination of the Jubilee of the World of Education, Pope Leo XIV proclaims Saint John Henry Newman a Doctor of the Church. His legacy, the Pope emphasized, is to form people "so that they may shine like stars in their full dignity.”

Read all

item.title: 'One in Christ, united in mission' theme of World Mission Sunday 2026
item.description:
The Vatican has announced the theme chosen by Pope Leo XIV for World Missions Day 2026: "One in Christ, united in mission." President Donald Trump is slashing the number of refugees allowed into the United States, and people fleeing war-torn countries, human rights abuses and catastrophes will now be of lower priority than white people from South Africa.

item.title: Trump sets refugee ceiling at record-low 7,500

item.title: ‘Blood on the sand. Blood on the hands’: UN decries world’s failure as Sudan’s El Fasher falls
item.description: El Fasher has “descended into an even darker hell,” senior UN officials warned on Thursday, as the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) militia seized control of the North Darfur capital after a 500-day siege, forcing tens of thousands to flee on foot amid reports of mass executions, rape and starvation.
item.source:markdown: El Fasher has “descended into an even darker hell,” senior UN officials warned on Thursday, as the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) militia seized control of the North Darfur capital after a 500-day siege, forcing tens of thousands to flee on foot amid reports of mass executions, rape and starvation.

item.title: Security Council LIVE: Ambassadors meet in emergency session on Sudan
item.description: Reports of mass atrocities in and around the newly-captured city of El Fasher in Darfur mark a new low in Sudan's brutal civil war and the Security Council met in emergency session on Thursday morning in New York to address the rapidly deteriorating situation. Civilians are facing starvation and mass displacement as the UN continues providing lifesaving aid throughout the country. Follow our in-depth live coverage; UN News app users can go here.
item.source:markdown: Reports of mass atrocities in and around the newly-captured city of El Fasher in Darfur mark a new low in Sudan's brutal civil war and the Security Council met in emergency session on Thursday morning in New York to address the rapidly deteriorating situation. item.title: Over 100 killed in Rio police crackdown on powerful gang

item.title: Carney, Trump keep it civil at South Korea summit, but speak little
item.description: U.S. President Donald Trump and Prime Minister Mark Carney were seated across the table and even acknowledged each other during a toast at a dinner ahead of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation Summit, but the two appeared to have virtually nothing to say to one another amid the U.S.-Canada trade war.

item.title: Heat-related deaths rise due to climate change - report

item.title: Dutch go to the polls in test for Europe's far right

item.title: Exit poll suggests centrists win Dutch vote
item.description: Dutch voters appeared to have shunned far-right leader Geert Wilders in favour of a centrist party, exit polls have suggested, after a snap election watched closely in Europe where extremists are gaining ground.
item.source:markdown: Dutch voters appeared to have shunned far-right leader Geert Wilders in favour of a centrist party, exit polls have suggested, after a snap election watched closely in Europe where extremists are gaining ground.

item.title: If China invades Taiwan, these islands would be on the front line. But there's little panic here
item.description: CBC News visited Taiwan’s Kinmen islands, which are just a few kilometres across the bay from the Chinese city of Xiamen. The islands have been on the frontline of hostilities between China and Taiwan for more than seven decades. Many Kinmen locals say they don’t believe war with China is near — despite mounting evidence to the contrary.
item.source:markdown:
![The view of Xiamen, China from Taiwan's Kinmen Islands, just a few kilometers across the bay. Kinmen's beaches are covered with relics from past conflicts, including anti-tank defences.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/fc94a8e5-4c7a-4628-b48f-0d0b95a06f8d,1761599088584/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C3840%2C2160%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
CBC News visited Taiwan’s Kinmen islands, which are just a few kilometres across the bay from the Chinese city of Xiamen. The islands have been on the frontline of hostilities between China and Taiwan for more than seven decades. Many Kinmen locals say they don’t believe war with China is near — despite mounting evidence to the contrary.

item.title: Hurricane Melissa comes ashore in Jamaica as catastrophic Cat. 5 storm
item.description: Heavy floodwaters swept across southwestern Jamaica, winds tore roofs off buildings and boulders tumbled into roads Tuesday as Hurricane Melissa came ashore as a catastrophic Category 5 storm, one of the strongest Atlantic hurricanes in history.
item.source:markdown:

item.title: Pope to the new nuncio in Iraq: Foster hope and peace
item.description:
On 26 October in Saint Peter’s Basilica, Pope Leo XIV presided over the Mass with the episcopal ordination of Monsignor Mirosław Stanisław Wachowski, the new papal representative to Iraq. In his homily, the Pope urges him to foster “peaceful coexistence” and to collaborate “constructively” with other religions, in a land “marked by suffering and by the desire for rebirth.”

Read all
item.source:markdown:
On 26 October in Saint Peter’s Basilica, Pope Leo XIV presided over the Mass with the episcopal ordination of Monsignor Mirosław Stanisław Wachowski, the new papal representative to Iraq. In his homily, the Pope urges him to foster “peaceful coexistence” and to collaborate “constructively” with other religions, in a land “marked by suffering and by the desire for rebirth.”

item.title: Pope approves beatification for priests martyred under Nazism and Communism
item.description:
Pope Leo XIV approves the upcoming beatification of nine Polish priests martyred at Dachau and Auschwitz; and two diocesan priests killed out of “hatred of the faith” by the Communist regime that ruled Czechoslovakia in the 1950s. The Holy Father also promulgates decrees concerning four new Venerables: a Spanish Cistercian nun, a Spanish Dominican priest, an Italian diocesan priest, and an Italian Carmelite friar.

item.title: Pope to Estonian pilgrims: 'Your ecumenical witness is the antithesis to hatred'
item.description:
Pope Leo XIV reminds pilgrims from Estonia in Rome for the Jubilee that their ecumenical witness is the "very antithesis of the hatred that was so tragically visible during the Soviet regime’s persecution of the Church" and urges them "to pray fervently for peace" while "we still see the logic of war being perpetrated in Europe."

Read all
item.source:markdown:
Pope Leo XIV reminds pilgrims from Estonia in Rome for the Jubilee that their ecumenical witness is the "very antithesis of the hatred that was so tragically visible during the Soviet regime’s persecution of the Church" and urges them "to pray fervently for peace" while "we still see the logic of war being perpetrated in Europe."
[Read all](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/pope/news/2025-10/pope-leo-xiv-jubilee-pilgrimage-estonia-address-24-october-2025.html)

item.title: Gardaí awarded Scott medals for bravery in line of duty
item.description: Nine Scott medals have been awarded to gardaí for bravery in the line of duty, with two of them awarded posthumously.
item.source:markdown: Nine Scott medals have been awarded to gardaí for bravery in the line of duty, with two of them awarded posthumously.

item.title: Privacy groups raise concerns over new Data Commissioner
item.description: A group of privacy organisations, including the Irish Council for Civil Liberties, has written to the Government expressing concerns over the recent appointment of a third Commissioner of the Irish Data Protection Commission (DPC).
item.source:markdown: A group of privacy organisations, including the Irish Council for Civil Liberties, has written to the Government expressing concerns over the recent appointment of a third Commissioner of the Irish Data Protection Commission (DPC).

item.title: EU finds Meta and TikTok in breach of transparency rules
item.description: The European Commission has issued preliminary findings that both TikTok and Meta are in breach of their obligations to grant researchers adequate access to public data under the Digital Services Act (DSA).
item.source:markdown: The European Commission has issued preliminary findings that both TikTok and Meta are in breach of their obligations to grant researchers adequate access to public data under the Digital Services Act (DSA).

item.title: From Amazon to Lockheed Martin, these companies are helping build Trump's contentious White House ballroom
item.description: As Americans have posted "RIP East Wing 1902-2025" on social media platforms, the Democrats are promising to investigate how Donald Trump and his administration moved ahead with a White House demolition that has proceeded at a rapid pace. We now know more about who's donating to Trump's treasured ballroom project.

item.title: Canada ready to resume trade talks with US - Carney
item.description: Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney said that Canada stands ready to resume trade talks with the United States that President Donald Trump halted over an anti-tariff advertisement issued by Ontario's provincial government.

item.title: Trump says no plans to meet Carney in Asia after anti-tariff ad airs during World Series
item.description: U.S. President Donald Trump said in a late-night social media post that he is terminating all trade negotiations with Canada over an advertisement by the Ontario government that uses the late U.S. president Ronald Reagan's words to send an anti-tariff message to American audiences.

item.title: Zelensky asks coalition of willing for long-range weapons

item.title: Allies should boost Ukraine's missile reach, says UK
item.description: British Prime Minister Keir Starmer has urged allies to "finish the job" on Russian assets as he told Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelensky in London there was more that they could do to bolster Kyiv's long-range missile capability.

item.title: Health unions 'not satisfied' with HSE staffing response

item.title: Trump backs away from sending federal agents to San Francisco
item.description: Donald Trump will not deploy federal agents to San Francisco, the U.S. president and the California city's mayor said in separate social media posts on Thursday, a surprising stand-down as Trump pressures Democratic-led cities around the country to step up enforcement against crime and illegal immigration.
item.source:markdown:
![A flock of geese flies in the sky over a crowd of protesters holding white placards with the message "No ICE troops in the Bay."](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/295d4043-3976-426e-89c5-f9cb81b218e0,1761270867347/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C143%2C4411%2C2481%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Donald Trump will not deploy federal agents to San Francisco, the U.S. president and the California city's mayor said in separate social media posts on Thursday, a surprising stand-down as Trump pressures Democratic-led cities around the country to step up enforcement against crime and illegal immigration.

item.title: Province hires MMIWG advocate Cambria Harris to work as special assistant on reconciliation
item.description: Cambria Harris, who was was one of the most prominent voices pushing for a landfill search for the remains of her mother, Morgan Harris, and those of Marcedes Myran, will join Manitoba's Finance Department as a special assistant, helping support work within the Indigenous reconciliation portfolio, a government spokesperson says.
item.source:markdown:
![A young woman wearing a camouflage jacket and a red backpack speaks into a microphone.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/1.7138426,1709926025000/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C1919%2C1079%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Cambria Harris, who was was one of the most prominent voices pushing for a landfill search for the remains of her mother, Morgan Harris, and those of Marcedes Myran, will join Manitoba's Finance Department as a special assistant, helping support work within the Indigenous reconciliation portfolio, a government spokesperson says.

item.title: Trump administration finalizes plan to open pristine Alaska wildlife refuge to oil and gas drilling
item.description: The Trump administration on Thursday finalized plans to open the coastal plain of Alaska's Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to potential oil and gas drilling, renewing a long-simmering debate over whether to drill in one of the nation's environmental jewels.
item.source:markdown:

The Trump administration on Thursday finalized plans to open the coastal plain of Alaska's Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to potential oil and gas drilling, renewing a long-simmering debate over whether to drill in one of the nation's environmental jewels.

item.title: FAA says flights delayed in N.Y., N.J., Texas and Washington, amid staffing issues
item.description: Air traffic control staffing issues are delaying travel at airports in New York, Washington, Newark and Houston, the U.S. Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) said late on Thursday, as a U.S. government shutdown hit its 23rd day.
item.source:markdown:
![A view of the top of an air traffic control tower](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/950115ba-d421-4b97-b6c2-0a3865e9d382,1761265768166/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C442%2C5000%2C2812%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Air traffic control staffing issues are delaying travel at airports in New York, Washington, Newark and Houston, the U.S. Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) said late on Thursday, as a U.S. government shutdown hit its 23rd day.

item.title: 16 people charged in court over Citywest disturbances
item.description: 15 men and one woman, ranging between 18 and 66 years of age, and with addresses in Dublin, Carlow, Galway and Laois, have appeared before Dublin District Court on public order charges in connection with disturbances at Saggart in County Dublin.

item.title: How 3 women beat Singapore’s strict protest laws | About That
item.description: In Singapore, protesting without permission from police is illegal, but that didn’t stop three women from organizing a watermelon umbrella march in solidarity with the Palestinian cause. Andrew Chang explains the charges against the organizers by breaking down Singapore’s strict rules on public assembly — and why these three women were ultimately acquitted. Images from Ng Yi-Sheng/Facebook, sgacadboycott/Instagram, MustShareNews, Getty Images, Reuters Thumbnail credit: sgacadboycott/Instagram
item.source:markdown:
![Photo of 3 women who beat Singapore’s strict protest laws.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/3cfe0263-4400-4c96-a2fc-23cca7688ab0,1761250813022/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C1920%2C1080%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
In Singapore, protesting without permission from police is illegal, but that didn’t stop three women from organizing a watermelon umbrella march in solidarity with the Palestinian cause. Andrew Chang explains the charges against the organizers by breaking down Singapore’s strict rules on public assembly — and why these three women were ultimately acquitted.
Images from Ng Yi-Sheng/Facebook, sgacadboycott/Instagram, MustShareNews, Getty Images, Reuters
Thumbnail credit: sgacadboycott/Instagram

item.title: US Bishop calls for remembering dignity of victims of Wounded Knee
item.description:
The Bishop of Rapid City, South Dakota, in the United States, underscores the need to respect the history surrounding the 1890 Wounded Knee Massacre when hundreds of native Lakota people were killed by soldiers at the time, as the US Secretary of Defense announced his intention to retain the Medals of Honor awarded to the soldiers participating in the massacre.

Read all
item.source:markdown:
The Bishop of Rapid City, South Dakota, in the United States, underscores the need to respect the history surrounding the 1890 Wounded Knee Massacre when hundreds of native Lakota people were killed by soldiers at the time, as the US Secretary of Defense announced his intention to retain the Medals of Honor awarded to the soldiers participating in the massacre.
[Read all](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/church/news/2025-10/us-bishop-calls-for-remembering-dignity-of-victims-wounded-knee.html)

item.title: King Charles receives Royal Confrater title as sign of 'hope' with Anglican Communion
item.description:
The British monarch is accorded the title "Royal Confrater" at the Basilica of Saint Paul Outside the Walls, taking a seat on a stall bearing the Gospel inscription, “That they may be one”. This wish is echoed by Cardinal Harvey, who, together with Abbot Ogliari, accompanies the Royals through the Holy Door before the ecumenical celebration.

Read all
item.source:markdown:
The British monarch is accorded the title "Royal Confrater" at the Basilica of Saint Paul Outside the Walls, taking a seat on a stall bearing the Gospel inscription, “That they may be one”. This wish is echoed by Cardinal Harvey, who, together with Abbot Ogliari, accompanies the Royals through the Holy Door before the ecumenical celebration.
[Read all](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/vatican-city/news/2025-10/king-charles-royal-confrater-saint-paul-outside-the-walls.html)

item.title: Fraternity and hope strengthen relations between Catholics and Anglicans
item.description:
Perspectives on the visit of the British Royal Family to the Vatican by Archbishop Pace, secretary of the Pontifical Council for Christian Unity, and Bishop Ball, director of the Anglican Centre in Rome. The warmth and gestures that accompanied it “nurture our confidence in the path of dialogue and engagement with one another to which our churches remain wholeheartedly committed. We continue to hope, as Pope Leo has expressed it, for ‘the re-establishment of full and visible communion.’”

item.title: Security Council LIVE: Gaza ceasefire, aid crisis dominates agenda as ambassadors meet on the Middle East
item.description: The UN Security Council is meeting in New York to debate the Middle East. The session comes amid faltering progress on the fragile Gaza ceasefire and mounting humanitarian needs after two years of war, with famine still looming in parts of the territory. Ambassadors will likely discuss yesterday's ICJ advisory opinion affirming Israel’s obligation to allow agencies aid access under international law. Follow our in-depth live coverage from 10am; UN News app users can go here.
item.source:markdown: The UN Security Council is meeting in New York to debate the Middle East. item.title: NFL stands by Bad Bunny as Super Bowl halftime headliner despite criticism from Trump

item.title: Why French ex-president Nicolas Sarkozy is now in jail | About That
item.description: How does a former French president end up behind bars in the isolation wing of a Paris prison? Andrew Chang explains the key charge against Nicolas Sarkozy that led to a criminal conspiracy conviction by breaking down his relationship to Libyan dictator Muammar Gaddafi, and why despite the guilty verdict — he's currently presumed innocent.
item.source:markdown:
![Photo collage of French ex-president Nicolas Sarkozy and the layout of his Paris prison cell.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/03012770-58c2-4ddd-a0eb-9df1e014af8a,1761162813873/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C1920%2C1080%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
How does a former French president end up behind bars in the isolation wing of a Paris prison? Andrew Chang explains the key charge against Nicolas Sarkozy that led to a criminal conspiracy conviction by breaking down his relationship to Libyan dictator Muammar Gaddafi, and why despite the guilty verdict — he's currently presumed innocent.

item.title: Security Council LIVE: UN discusses next phase to curb Haiti gang violence, step up aid
item.description: Following renewal of the Security Council’s sanctions regime in Haiti and a resolution to create a new Gang Suppression Force to combat the scourge of gang violence, ambassadors heard this afternoon from the top UN official in the country. In his first briefing as head of the UN office in Haiti (BINUH), Carlos Ruiz Massieu reported on latest developments, as brutal violence and insecurity continues to rage, increasing pressure on diplomats to act fast and decisively to protect millions of Haitians facing impunity and chaos. UN News app users can follow live coverage here.
item.source:markdown: Following renewal of the Security Council’s sanctions regime in Haiti and a resolution to create a new Gang Suppression Force to combat the scourge of gang violence, ambassadors heard this afternoon from the top UN official in the country. In his first briefing as head of the UN office in Haiti (BINUH), Carlos Ruiz Massieu reported on latest developments, as brutal violence and insecurity continues to rage, increasing pressure on diplomats to act fast and decisively to protect millions of Haitians facing impunity and chaos. UN News app users can follow live coverage here.

item.title: Israel is obliged to let aid flow into Occupied Palestinian Territory, says World Court

item.title: An advocate in a veil: Catholic sister defending justice in Kenyan courtrooms
item.description:
When people picture a Catholic religious sister, they image a woman in a habit, perhaps teaching, praying quietly in a chapel, or caring for the sick. Few imagine a religious sister in a courtroom, dressed in professional attire, standing before a judge, and introducing herself not just as “Advocate Immaculate Muthoni,” but as “Sister Immaculate.”

Read all
item.source:markdown:
When people picture a Catholic religious sister, they image a woman in a habit, perhaps teaching, praying quietly in a chapel, or caring for the sick. Few imagine a religious sister in a courtroom, dressed in professional attire, standing before a judge, and introducing herself not just as “Advocate Immaculate Muthoni,” but as “Sister Immaculate.”
[Read all](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/church/news/2025-10/sisters-project-150-kenya-lawyer-nun-defending-justice.html)

item.title: U.S. appeals court lets Trump send troops to Portland

item.title: Abuse survivors and activists meet Pope Leo: ‘We found listening and support'
item.description:
Pope Leo receives six members of ECA Global, an international human rights association that works for greater support and compensation for victims of abuse and calls for stronger commitment and cooperation from the Catholic Church. Participants describe the audience as “a historic and hope-filled step toward greater cooperation.”

item.title: Trump ending aid to Colombia after U.S. accused of murder for boat strike
item.description: U.S. President Donald Trump says he is ending aid to Colombia after the country’s president, Gustavo Petro, accused the U.S. of ‘murder’ when it struck a small boat within Colombian territorial waters in September. The U.S. alleges the boat was a drug vessel, but Petro said the fisherman killed onboard had no ties to the drug trade.
item.source:markdown:
![U.S. President Donald Trump on the left and Columbia's president Gustavo Petro on the right](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/6c02cfdf-e2af-46b3-8366-712596d98f7e,1760903880044/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C1280%2C720%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
U.S. President Donald Trump says he is ending aid to Colombia after the country’s president, Gustavo Petro, accused the U.S. of ‘murder’ when it struck a small boat within Colombian territorial waters in September. The U.S. alleges the boat was a drug vessel, but Petro said the fisherman killed onboard had no ties to the drug trade.

item.title: These wool producers are aiming to revitalize the natural fibre’s value in Europe
item.description: Across Europe and North America, the picture is bleak: wool is often burned or discarded because processing costs outweigh returns. item.title: Rail port project under provincial review signs prospective partnership agreement with First Nation
item.description: JohnQ Public has announced a proposed partnership with Chemawawin Cree Nation to turn agricultural land in the rural municipality of Ritchot into "one of Canada's first eco-industrial rail parks," even though the project initiated by the former Progressive Conservative government is now under review by the province's NDP government.
item.source:markdown:
![Four people standing in a field](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/29117d05-fcc1-4457-9ea1-713aee230890,1760658211762/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C80%2C1536%2C864%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
JohnQ Public has announced a proposed partnership with Chemawawin Cree Nation to turn agricultural land in the rural municipality of Ritchot into "one of Canada's first eco-industrial rail parks," even though the project initiated by the former Progressive Conservative government is now under review by the province's NDP government.

item.title: Madagascar's military coup leader is sworn in as president of beleaguered island nation
item.description: An army colonel who seized power in a military coup was sworn in as Madagascar's new leader Friday in a lightning-fast power grab that ousted the president and sent him fleeing from the country into hiding.
item.source:markdown:

An army colonel who seized power in a military coup was sworn in as Madagascar's new leader Friday in a lightning-fast power grab that ousted the president and sent him fleeing from the country into hiding.

item.title: Andrew Cuomo and Zohran Mamdani trade jabs in heated NYC mayoral debate
item.description: Former Gov. Andrew Cuomo entered Thursday evening's first New York mayoral debate trying to blunt Democratic front-runner Zohran Mamdani's momentum. Instead he spent much of the contentious faceoff on defence, batting away criticisms over his long tenure in office from Mamdani and Republican Curtis Sliwa.

Instead he spent much of the contentious faceoff on defence, batting away criticisms over his long tenure in office from Mamdani and Republican Curtis Sliwa.

item.title: Thousands of aid vehicles must reach Gaza weekly to ease crisis, UN's humanitarian relief chief says
item.description: The United Nations humanitarian relief chief is urging Israel to open up all entrances to Gaza to allow a surge of aid into the territory. item.title: Hundreds airlifted from storm-damaged villages in Alaska
item.description: One of the "most significant" airlifts in the history of Alaska is under way to move hundreds of people from villages on the US state's south-west coast that were inundated by the remnants of Typhoon Halong last weekend, officials said.

item.title: Indigenous leaders ‘not allowed’ to fully partake in ministers’ meeting on public safety, says national chief
item.description: The head of the Assembly of First Nations says she’s disappointed Indigenous leaders aren’t allowed to fully participate in this week’s first ministers’ meeting on public safety. Instead, Indigenous politicians got just an afternoon to address federal, provincial and territorial ministers before they were excluded, said National Chief Cindy Woodhouse-Nepinak.
item.source:markdown:
![A woman in a headdress speaks into a microphone.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/f74622bb-5ea9-435e-9c41-a25a70df7471,1760651168927/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C372%2C5101%2C2869%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
The head of the Assembly of First Nations says she’s disappointed Indigenous leaders aren’t allowed to fully participate in this week’s first ministers’ meeting on public safety. Instead, Indigenous politicians got just an afternoon to address federal, provincial and territorial ministers before they were excluded, said National Chief Cindy Woodhouse-Nepinak.

item.title: Kieran Quilligan suffered multiple fractures, court hears
item.description: The trial of two men for the murder of Kieran Quilligan - who had been missing for five months - has been told that there were multiple fractures to his bones, consistent with blows from a blunt weapon, similar to a hammer.

item.title: 'Disturbing' retaliation for abuse victims - Vatican body

item.title: Trump, Putin to meet after progress in Ukraine talks
item.description: US President Donald Trump said he and Russian President Vladimir Putin agreed to another summit to discuss ending the war in Ukraine, one day before the US president was due to speak with Ukrainian leader Volodymyr Zelensky.
item.source:markdown: US President Donald Trump said he and Russian President Vladimir Putin agreed to another summit to discuss ending the war in Ukraine, one day before the US president was due to speak with Ukrainian leader Volodymyr Zelensky.

item.title: Trump says he'll meet with Putin again after 'great progress' in Thursday phone call
item.description: U.S. President Donald Trump said Thursday he will meet again with Russian President Vladimir Putin in person, in an effort to end the war in Ukraine. A date has not been set, but Trump wrote on social media that the meeting would take place in Budapest, Hungary. The call came ahead of Trump's meeting on Friday at the White House with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy.
item.source:markdown:
![Vladimir Putin standing next to Donald Trump.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/b2c6cf37-a122-4272-9e23-243b0e220874,1760639875770/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C108%2C3169%2C1782%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
U.S. President Donald Trump said Thursday he will meet again with Russian President Vladimir Putin in person, in an effort to end the war in Ukraine. A date has not been set, but Trump wrote on social media that the meeting would take place in Budapest, Hungary. The call came ahead of Trump's meeting on Friday at the White House with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy.

item.title: EU presents roadmap for defence readiness by 2030

item.title: Irish dancing body warns over impact of legal actions

item.title: Zambia: PMS-Solwezi Diocese promotes ‘A Million Children Praying the Rosary’
item.description:
The Pontifical Mission Societies (PMS) in the Catholic Diocese of Solwezi recently launched ‘A Million Children Praying the Rosary for Peace and Unity in the World’ campaign 2025. This initiative aimed to encourage school children to participate in a global prayer movement that recognises the Rosary as a powerful spiritual tool to foster peace and unity worldwide.

Read all
item.source:markdown:
The Pontifical Mission Societies (PMS) in the Catholic Diocese of Solwezi recently launched ‘A Million Children Praying the Rosary for Peace and Unity in the World’ campaign 2025. This initiative aimed to encourage school children to participate in a global prayer movement that recognises the Rosary as a powerful spiritual tool to foster peace and unity worldwide.

item.title: World Food Day LIVE: The task of feeding the world
item.description: Amid the destruction of the Second World War, nations responded to the danger of hunger and malnutrition by creating the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) on 16 October 1945. The UN agency celebrates this achievement as World Food Day every year on its birthday, recognizing the work of all those who are committed to ensuring food for everyone. We’ll be bringing you the highlights live from FAO throughout the day. UN News app users can follow coverage here.
item.source:markdown: Amid the destruction of the Second World War, nations responded to the danger of hunger and malnutrition by creating the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) on 16 October 1945. The UN agency celebrates this achievement as World Food Day every year on its birthday, recognizing the work of all those who are committed to ensuring food for everyone. We’ll be bringing you the highlights live from FAO throughout the day. UN News app users can follow coverage here.

item.title: Trump's Gaza deal may be 'historic,' but falls short of delivering 'dawn of a new Middle East'
item.description: The killing has stopped. Surviving Israeli hostages have been released to their families, while hundreds of Palestinians held by Israel have been returned to theirs. But to call an end to the Gaza war, as Trump did, the “historic dawn of a new Middle East” wildly overstates what the deal delivers.
item.source:markdown:
![A swath of road is filled with people walking north, with dusty land on either side and buildings along the horizon.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/33a06d0a-b9ec-4d21-8ce4-403e4d8e8cc6,1760624324928/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C138%2C2645%2C1487%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
The killing has stopped. Surviving Israeli hostages have been released to their families, while hundreds of Palestinians held by Israel have been returned to theirs. But to call an end to the Gaza war, as Trump did, the “historic dawn of a new Middle East” wildly overstates what the deal delivers.

item.title: A saint to be for a nation: Peter To Rot’s witness shapes Papua New Guinea
item.description:
Pope St. John Paul II declared Peter To Rot Blessed, in 1995, as the first Martyr of Papua New Guinea, as a new figure of holiness is a layman a husband, father, teacher, and catechist. Pope Francis approved his canonization on March 31, 2025, and he will be canonized on 19 October 2025 by Pope Leo XIV and be formally recognized as the first saint from Papua New Guinea, and six other Blesseds from other countries.

Read all
item.source:markdown:
Pope St. John Paul II declared Peter To Rot Blessed, in 1995, as the first Martyr of Papua New Guinea, as a new figure of holiness is a layman a husband, father, teacher, and catechist. Pope Francis approved his canonization on March 31, 2025, and he will be canonized on 19 October 2025 by Pope Leo XIV and be formally recognized as the first saint from Papua New Guinea, and six other Blesseds from other countries.
[Read all](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/church/news/2025-10/a-saint-to-be-for-a-nation-peter-to-rot-s-witness-shapes-papua.html)

item.title: Indigenous-led film finds perfect home on First Nation in Sask.
item.description: When Rueben Martell was looking for locations to shoot his Indigenous love story A Life Less Empty, he knew he wanted it to be on a reserve in his home province of Saskatchewan. After months of searching, he and his film crew finally found the ideal location — an abandoned house on Pheasant Rump Nakota Nation, about 150 kilometres southeast of Regina.
item.source:markdown:
![An Indigenous man standing in front of an old house on a movie set](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/97c0c19c-a8b8-4835-92f7-99b3686a8f36,1760574486850/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C561%2C5712%2C3213%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)

item.title: Alberta beef entering Mexico’s Costco market where U.S. cuts once reigned
item.description: Alberta beef is now stocked in the meat section of Costco Mexico's 41 locations, joining a host of other Canadian products on the shelves of the retail giant in the country. item.title: He's one of the most celebrated Indigenous artists — and one of the most forged
item.description: A new podcast, Forged, investigates the massive art forgery of Norval Morrisseau's paintings. Today on Commotion, Forged host and Indigenous artist Adrian Stimson sits down with host Elamin Abdelmahmoud to discuss what is possibly the largest art crime fraud ever.

item.title: Tanzania: On Nyerere Day, Archbishop Ruwa’ichi calls for an end to abductions
item.description:
In commemorating Nyerere Day—when Tanzanians honour the country’s Founding Father, Mwalimu Julius Kambarage Nyerere—on 14 October 2025, the Archbishop of the Archdiocese of Dar es Salaam and Chairperson of the Justice and Peace Commission for the Tanzania Episcopal Conference (TEC) issued a passionate appeal concerning a troubling rise in unexplained disappearances and kidnappings across the country. The abductions have persisted in Tanzania for the past two years.

Read all
item.source:markdown:
In commemorating Nyerere Day—when Tanzanians honour the country’s Founding Father, Mwalimu Julius Kambarage Nyerere—on 14 October 2025, the Archbishop of the Archdiocese of Dar es Salaam and Chairperson of the Justice and Peace Commission for the Tanzania Episcopal Conference (TEC) issued a passionate appeal concerning a troubling rise in unexplained disappearances and kidnappings across the country. The abductions have persisted in Tanzania for the past two years.
[Read all](https://www.vaticannews.va/en/africa/news/2025-10/tanzania-on-nyerere-day-archbishop-ruwa-ichi-calls-for-an-end.html)

item.title: Canadian woman's boyfriend to serve at least 25 years for her murder on remote Scottish island
item.description: A Scottish jury has convicted a man of killing his Canadian girlfriend in the remote Shetland Islands of Scotland. Aren Pearson, 41, was found guilty Wednesday of assault and murder in the death of 24-year-old Claire Leveque, who had been living and working in Edmonton.
item.source:markdown:
![Aren Pearson, right, was charged with the death of 24-year-old Claire Leveque of Edmonton.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/1.7401354,1760490458959/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C184%2C526%2C295%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
A Scottish jury has convicted a man of killing his Canadian girlfriend in the remote Shetland Islands of Scotland. Aren Pearson, 41, was found guilty Wednesday of assault and murder in the death of 24-year-old Claire Leveque, who had been living and working in Edmonton.

item.title: Trump says U.S. financial support for Argentina could hinge on their midterm election results
item.description: U.S. support for Argentina hinges on the ruling party of President Javier Milei succeeding in this month's midterm legislative elections, President Donald Trump said on Tuesday, roiling markets in the South American country with what could be the Republican's most overt intervention in a foreign vote.

A dark haired man smiles while holding documents, as a blonde-haired man speask.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/dc4a46f2-40ba-4c34-a37c-dfa431c27ddc,1760529646965/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C3590%2C2019%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)

item.title: Canada's plan to donate refurbished armour to Ukraine appears to be on the scrap heap
item.description: Ukraine was supposed to receive more than two dozen rebuilt light armoured vehicles from Canada in a deal brokered through a federal agency. ![A military vehicle is seen operated in the desert.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/36dc1e77-3e1b-4406-9d27-b3c4c9ae9367,1760477296524/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C421%2C3072%2C1728%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)

item.title: World's coral reefs in almost irreversible die-off, scientists say
item.description: Global warming is crossing dangerous thresholds sooner than expected, with the world's coral reefs now in an almost irreversible die-off, marking what scientists on Monday described as the first "tipping point" in climate-driven ecosystem collapse.
item.source:markdown:
![Tiny fish are seen around bleached coral.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/165885ae-e6d6-49e0-af86-826df91d119c,1760451147415/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C172%2C3298%2C1855%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Global warming is crossing dangerous thresholds sooner than expected, with the world's coral reefs now in an almost irreversible die-off, marking what scientists on Monday described as the first "tipping point" in climate-driven ecosystem collapse.

item.title: Dozens dead, missing, thousands of homes destroyed after rains sweep across Mexico
item.description: Four days of heavy rains fell unexpectedly across five Mexican states last week, leaving devastated lives and communities. The rains caused rivers, gullies and ditches to overflow, triggering landslides that washed out highways and roads, and leaving dozens dead and missing.
item.source:markdown:
![A group of soliders strap a boulder on the road to a pick up truck.](https://i.cbc.ca/ais/044776c7-c788-4cd4-adae-9fa4b541f2c2,1760386922242/full/max/0/default.jpg?im=Crop%2Crect%3D%280%2C0%2C1280%2C720%29%3BResize%3D%28620%29)
Four days of heavy rains fell unexpectedly across five Mexican states last week, leaving devastated lives and communities. The rains caused rivers, gullies and ditches to overflow, triggering landslides that washed out highways and roads, and leaving dozens dead and missing.
